Description: Large marl pottery jar with small flat base, expanding to a wide shoulder, with low, slightly inset neck and everted rim, decorated in red paint with wavy lines, two antelopes, a fan-shaped bush motif and s-motifs.
Curator's comments: Shape and decorative arrangement Like Decorated ware D51K in Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921). Six wavy lines encircle the shoulder just below the neck. Hanging down from them on opposite sides of the body are two semi-circular arrangements of wavy lines, called ‘festoons’. Between the festoons, two pairs of wavy lines run down the pot, crossing each other and arching below the festoons. In the space above the crossing of the lines on each side is a figure of an antelope, identified as an addax based on the twisted horns. Both face left and have slender bodies, bandy legs and short upturned tails. A bush motif and a series of vertical s-motifs complete the decoration. Published: G. Graff, Les peintures sur vases de Naqada I–Naqada II: Nouvelle approche sémiologique de l’iconographie prédynastique, Leuven (2009), cat. no. 310. G. Graff, Construire l'image - ordonner le réel. les vases peints du IVème millénaire en Egypte, Paris (2013), 36, 74-75. G Graff, The iconography on Decorated ware, in G. Graff and A. Jimenez-Serrano (eds), Prehistories of Writing, Provence (2016), p. 50
